title: pbe "balances" - Lux ???

embed.description: Continue reading for more information! ( Warning : PBE Content is tentative and subject to change - what you see below may not reflect what eventually gets pushed to live servers at the end of the cycle! Manage your expectations accordingly.)

body:
Since I don't have a PBE account, this is the only place I can go to complain where Riot might see it (unlikely). 
What's the deal with the Lux changes? This isn't balancing anything, I see no balance in a 15 second ult (with a stacking cool-down on multiple kills) at max cdr and level. 
Lux does not need this, she's in a great spot as is. Isn't over-played, isn't under-played, can still hold her lane while simultaneously having weaknesses to exploit.
A 500 base damage and 75% ap scaling ULTIMATE ability does not need this.

They're acting like Lux doesn't ALWAYS get the kill with her ult, it literally half-healths squishies even without her passive.
Lux is in a fairly good position already, she isn't a plague like Lee and Cait, and she isn't a "if you play her properly, you win." champ like Vayne or Hecarim.
She's already strong, yes its true she cant make many 'cool' or 'interesting' plays because her kit is simple, but the trade off is: She isn't very difficult to play or master.

Now, I'm no gameplay science professor from Cambridge, but it seems to me that making easy champs stronger.. is a bad idea.

I know its not as profound as E=MC2 or anything, but my calculation is: 
Easy champs are easy to play _(pro)_, but they shouldn't affect the outcome of the game as strongly _(con)_, while difficult champs are very hard to play _(con)_, but if you master them, theres more options they have to help win, _(pro)_.

If both sets of champs (easy and hard) can affect the outcome equally. Why would anyone ever play difficult champions? There needs to be a reason for people to sit there for hours practicing Kalista or Anivia, otherwise they'll just sit there collecting dust while everyone plays Lux/Garen/Ezreal etc etc.

I feel like that should be common sense? maybe not...

and not just lux either, Kat with a 15 sec cooldown?
She's supposed to have a 15 sec cooldown AFTER getting a triple kill... not before...
Sure they're nerfing her early game potential, but it isn't her ult that makes her scary in lane. But it IS what makes her scary later on in the game.

Not to mention Jinx and Alistar are pretty strong too. Why do they need buffs?

What is going on?

"We consult pros on our balance changes"

because lets face it, the pros are good enough to not be completely facerolled by an OP champion, but in bronze/silver, any champ that is slightly more OP than the rest just dominates completely, and nothing gets done about it because it doesn't affect the pros.

As it is, only 25 or so champs even get used in worlds anyway, so why bother trying to balance all 150ish to fakers level of skill?

Thats true, but it does reach a point where the majority needs to win out.

For example, Mcdonalds could price their burgers at $40 each, because people like Bill gates and Donald Trump etc etc will still buy them. But its the non-billionaires that miss out.
Its not a good business plan because the majority cant use Mcdonalds anymore.

Thats just what Riot is doing, they are balancing the game around 8% of players. 
it just doesn't make sense.

True but there slightly different bussiness models. Trying to balance around the low elos, which the majority of the players are would cause utter havoc with the pro scene. 

Azir is a good example. Was considered pretty average in the lower teirs but if you knew what you were doing he was terrifying. After he became an almost 100% pick ban he was nerfed. But if you balance on the lower elos he never gets nerfed. Which would negatively effect the pro scene. 

Maybe the answer is to keep balancing on the pro scene. It pay more attention to the lower levels. I for one would welcome an in depth series that explores the op champs and shows lower elo players there weaknesses.

Because of the skill difference between all the different devisions, havoc will always be caused somewhere, no matter what you do. The point is:  
Is it better to cause havoc in the pro-scene (less than 0.03% of all players)
Or to have havoc in low elo (91.54% of all players.)?

Azir is a good example of what should be done tbh.
Some champs who are on the extreme ends of the skill level (Azir, Kalista, Garen, Yi etc.) will always be problems somewhere. Hard champs are too strong in high elo because they have so much potential, and are weak in low elo, because people don't have the mechanics for them. While easy champs are too weak in high elo because they can be outplayed too easily, but they are overbearing in low elo because they are piss easy to use, and shit over everyone who is actually trying.

So when you nerf the hard champs in high elo, they become unplayable in low elo, and when you nerf the easy champs in low elo, they become even less playable in high elo.

The problem is, that Riot doesn't want to make any champions 'unplayable' In any elo. So they try to balance the champions globally. Which means the hard champs end up being slightly too hard for low elo but have not quite enough power for pro-play. And the easy champions become way too strong for low elo, but not have enough playmaking potential for high elo.

So in the end, no one wins. _(except maybe mid plat players?)_

Azir was a 'unwanted' solution in Riot's eyes. They tried to balance him globally, failed, then gave up, and through a whole season of Riot negligence, he became a monster. Then when everyone was fed up and complaining, and worlds was fast approaching, Riot had their backs to the wall and the only thing they could do was nerf him in pro-play and make him 'unplayable' in low elo.

And tbh, thats what they should do for all extreme cases, Riot just needs to accept that Azir, Kalista, Sol etc etc. as they are today, will never be huge in low elo. So they shouldn't try, and they should just focus their efforts on making them less fucked-up in worlds, and let low elo have a few less champs.
Meanwhile, they need to accept that Garen, Master Yi and Tryndamere etc. are just too simple for pro-play and are likely not going to be key players in worlds anyway. So they need to nerf them in low elo, and accept that they will make even less of an appearance in pro-play. 

People in low elo who absolutely love Azir and Sol etc _(myself)_ will still be able to play them, _(its just how much effort you put in)_. Im high-bronze/low-silver, and I have had 70+ winrates on both of them, despite them being 'unplayable' at the time, in low elo. 

Meanwhile in pro-play it doesn't mater who you play, because its just all about winning, so no one plays champs they like the look of, or the playstyle of, they just play the statistically strongest champs in that specific patch. So Garen and Yi etc wont be missed at all.

And its not like _"Oh you're letting the retards in bronze balance the game? thats stupid, they all have an IQ of 6, what do you expect them to do?"_
There are people in bronze silver and gold, that know the game inside out, but just lack the mechanics/reflexes, or are not good under pressure, and so they don't climb well.
If you're in low elo, it doesn't _necessarily_ mean you're a complete retard and don't know shit about whats good for the game.

Thats my take on it anyway.
